description: Find out if, and how, you need to register with HMRC when you start employing people.

details.body:
You normally need to register as an employer with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) when you start employing staff, or using subcontractors for construction work.

You must register even if you’re only employing yourself, for example as the only director of a limited company.

You must register before the first payday. It can take up to 15 working days to get your employer PAYE reference number. You cannot register more than 2 months before you start paying people.

To pay an employee before you get your employer PAYE reference number, you should:

  1. Run payroll.

  2. Store your full payment submission.

  3. Send a late full payment submission to HMRC.

If you’re a limited company with 1 to 9 directors

Most limited companies can register online.

Start now

You can also continue an application if you’ve already started registering.

nodes.title: Will the business do any of the following?

nodes.body:

  • a receiver paying employees of companies in receivership
  • an offshore employer, including if you’re on the Isle of Man, that’s not liable for UK National Insurance
  • a registrar or Roman Catholic priest
  • an employee responsible for deducting your own tax and/or National Insurance (including certain employees of foreign embassies and consulates)
  • a provider of non-cash incentive awards using a taxed award scheme to pay the tax due

nodes.body:
However, you’ll need to register if any of your employees:

  • start earning more than £123 a week
  • get a pension or another job while still working for you
  • start getting any expenses or benefits

You’ll still need to keep records of what you pay them.
nodes.title: You do not need to register

nodes.body:
Contact HMRC - they’ll arrange for someone to call you back to help you register.

Contact HMRC’s Incentive Award Unit on 03000 577 340 if you need to set up a taxed award scheme.

What happens next

Once you’ve registered, you’ll get a letter containing your PAYE and Accounts Office references. You’ll need these to report and pay PAYE tax and National Insurance to HMRC. This normally arrives within 15 working days.

Finally, you’ll need to enrol for PAYE Online before you can send payroll information to HMRC.
nodes.title: You should register by phone or post

nodes.body:
You can register as an employer with HMRC by enrolling for PAYE in your online account.

After you enrol you’ll get 2 letters from HMRC containing your:

  • PAYE and Accounts Office references (within 15 working days)
  • activation code for PAYE Online (within 10 working days)

You’ll need these to set up your payroll and send information about your employees to HMRC.

Other ways to register

You can send your details to HMRC securely online using a register as an employer - sole trader form.

You’ll get a letter containing your PAYE and Accounts Office references within 15 working days.

Use these to enrol for PAYE Online.
nodes.title: Register by enrolling for PAYE Online

nodes.body:
You need to register as an employer by phoning HMRC.

What you’ll need to provide

When you phone HMRC, you’ll need to provide information about your partnership, including:

  • its name and registered address
  • its trading name, if this is different
  • the type of business, for example plumbing, investment, electrical engineering
  • its unique taxpayer reference (UTR)
  • the names and National Insurance numbers of each partner

You’ll also need to provide:

  • your name, email address and a telephone number HMRC can contact you on
  • a postal address for correspondence, if this is different to the partnership address

Finally, you’ll need to provide the following information about your employees:

  • the date of their payday, or when you first provide expenses or benefits if this is earlier
  • how many people you’re employing - or expect to employ in this tax year
  • whether you’ll be using any subcontractors in the construction industry

What happens next

Once you’ve registered, you’ll get a letter containing your PAYE and Accounts Office references. You’ll need these to report and pay PAYE tax and National Insurance to HMRC. This normally arrives within 15 working days.

Finally, you’ll need to enrol for PAYE Online before you can send payroll information to HMRC.

What happens next

Once you’ve registered, you’ll get a letter containing your PAYE and Accounts Office references. You’ll need these to report and pay PAYE tax and National Insurance to HMRC. This normally arrives within 15 working days.

Most people have to enrol for PAYE Online and send payroll information to HMRC online.

Reporting on paper if you’re exempt

You may be exempt from reporting payroll online if:

  • you’re prevented from using a computer on religious grounds
  • you’re getting care or support services for yourself or a member of your family
  • you’re unable to send reports electronically because you’re disabled, elderly or cannot access the internet

HMRC has guidance if you believe you’re exempt and would prefer to report on paper.

nodes.body:
You need to register as an employer by phoning HMRC.

What you’ll need to provide

When you phone HMRC, you’ll need to provide information about your company, including:

  • its name, registered address and phone number
  • its trading name, if this is different
  • the type of business, for example plumbing, investment, electrical engineering
  • its unique taxpayer reference (UTR)
  • its company registration number
  • the names and National Insurance numbers of all company directors - unless your company’s not based in the UK, or any directors have been advised by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) that they do not qualify for a number

You’ll also need to provide:

  • your name, email address and a telephone number HMRC can contact you on
  • a postal address for correspondence, if this is different to the company’s address

Finally, you’ll need to provide the following information about your employees:

  • the date of their first payday, or when you first provide expenses or benefits if this is earlier
  • how many people you’re employing - or expect to employ in this tax year
  • whether you’ll be using any subcontractors in the construction industry
  • whether you’ll be operating an occupational pension scheme

What happens next

Once you’ve registered, you’ll get a letter containing your PAYE and Accounts Office references. You’ll need these to report and pay PAYE tax and National Insurance to HMRC. This normally arrives within 15 working days.

Finally, you’ll need to enrol for PAYE Online before you can send payroll information to HMRC.
